apps:create.examples:
$ heroku apps:create
Creating app... done, stack is heroku-18
https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

# or just
$ heroku create

# use a heroku.yml manifest file
$ heroku apps:create --manifest

# specify a buildpack
$ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

# specify a name
$ heroku apps:create example

# create a staging app
$ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

# create an app in the eu region
$ heroku apps:create --region eu

addons.name: addons
addons.description: comma-delimited list of addons to install

buildpack.name: buildpack
buildpack.description: buildpack url to use for this app

manifest.name: manifest
manifest.description: use heroku.yml settings for this app

no-remote.name: no-remote
no-remote.description: do not create a git remote

remote.name: remote
remote.description: the git remote to create, default "heroku"

stack.name: stack
stack.description: the stack to create the app on

space.name: space
space.description: the private space to create the app in

region.name: region
region.description: specify region for the app to run in

ssh-git.name: ssh-git
ssh-git.description: use SSH git protocol for local git remote

internal-routing.name: internal-routing
internal-routing.description: private space-only. create as an Internal Web App that is only routable in the local network.

create.examples:
$ heroku apps:create
Creating app... done, stack is heroku-18
https://floating-dragon-42.heroku.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/floating-dragon-42.git

# or just
$ heroku create

# use a heroku.yml manifest file
$ heroku apps:create --manifest

# specify a buildpack
$ heroku apps:create --buildpack https://github.com/some/buildpack.git

# specify a name
$ heroku apps:create example

# create a staging app
$ heroku apps:create example-staging --remote staging

# create an app in the eu region
$ heroku apps:create --region eu

apps:info.description:
show detailed app information
$ heroku apps:info
=== example
Git URL:   https://git.heroku.com/example.git
Repo Size: 5M
...

$ heroku apps:info --shell
git_url=https://git.heroku.com/example.git
repo_size=5000000
...

shell.name: shell
shell.description: output more shell friendly key/value pairs

apps:open.description: open the app in a web browser
apps:open.examples:
$ heroku open -a myapp
# opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com

$ heroku open -a myapp /foo
# opens https://myapp.herokuapp.com/foo

apps:rename.description:
rename an app
This will locally update the git remote if it is set to the old app.
apps:rename.examples:
$ heroku apps:rename --app oldname newname
https://newname.herokuapp.com/ | https://git.heroku.com/newname.git
Git remote heroku updated

apps:stacks:set.description: set the stack of an app
apps:stacks:set.examples:
$ heroku stack:set heroku-18 -a myapp
Stack set. Next release on myapp will use heroku-18.
Run git push heroku master to create a new release on myapp.

config:set.description: set one or more config vars
config:set.examples:
$ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging
Setting config vars and restarting example... done, v10
RAILS_ENV: staging

$ heroku config:set RAILS_ENV=staging RACK_ENV=staging
Setting config vars and restarting example... done, v11
RAILS_ENV: staging
RACK_ENV:  staging

keys:add.description:
add an SSH key for a user
if no KEY is specified, will try to find ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub
keys:add.examples:
$ heroku keys:add
Could not find an existing public key.
Would you like to generate one? [Yn] y
Generating new SSH public key.
Uploading SSH public key /.ssh/id_rsa.pub... done

$ heroku keys:add /my/key.pub
Uploading SSH public key /my/key.pub... done

yes.name: yes
yes.description: automatically answer yes for all prompts

keys:clear.description: remove all SSH keys for current user

keys:remove.description: remove an SSH key from the user
keys:remove.examples:
$ heroku keys:remove email@example.com
Removing email@example.com SSH key... done

ps.examples:
$ heroku ps
=== run: one-off dyno
run.1: up for 5m: bash

=== web: bundle exec thin start -p $PORT
web.1: created for 30s

$ heroku ps run # specifying types
=== run: one-off dyno
run.1: up for 5m: bash

remote.description: git remote of app to use

ps:restart.description:
restart app dynos
if DYNO is not specified, restarts all dynos on app
ps:restart.examples:
$ heroku ps:restart web.1
Restarting web.1 dyno... done

$ heroku ps:restart web
Restarting web dynos... done

$ heroku ps:restart
Restarting dynos... done

remote.name: remote
remote.description: git remote of app to use

dyno:restart.examples:

ps:scale.description:
scale dyno quantity up or down
Appending a size (eg. web=2:Standard-2X) allows simultaneous scaling and resizing.

Omitting any arguments will display the app's current dyno formation, in a
format suitable for passing back into ps:scale.
ps:scale.examples:
$ heroku ps:scale web=3:Standard-2X worker+1
Scaling dynos... done, now running web at 3:Standard-2X, worker at 1:Standard-1X.

$ heroku ps:scale
web=3:Standard-2X worker=1:Standard-1X

remote.name: remote
remote.description: git remote of app to use

ps:type.description:
manage dyno sizes

Called with no arguments shows the current dyno size.

Called with one argument sets the size.
Where SIZE is one of free|hobby|standard-1x|standard-2x|performance

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

remote.name: remote
remote.description: git remote of app to use

Called with 1..n TYPE=SIZE arguments sets the quantity per type.

releases.description: display the releases for an app
releases.examples:
$ heroku releases
=== example Releases
v1 Config add FOO_BAR email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
v2 Config add BAR_BAZ email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
v3 Config add BAZ_QUX email@example.com 2015/11/17 17:37:41 (~ 1h ago)
